title: arstechnica.com/information-te...

last_post.content:
Computers have been beating the best human Go players since 2016. The Go world champion retired in part because AI is “an entity that cannot be defeated.”

But a human just trounced one of the world’s best Go AIs 14 games to 1: https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/man-beats-machine-at-go-in-human-victory-over-ai

I think this news story is more interesting than it might first appear (without knowing details, so grain of salt). It isn’t just a gaming curiosity; it points to a fundamental flaw with “deep learning” approaches in general.
1/

title: Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

last_post.content:
This obsessed woman is more than discouraged by the fact that yesterday there were the lowest number of daily signatures, 81, since this petition started

As I write there are 92,276 signatures on the petition. The ETA for 100,000 signatures is now Wednesday 10 May, in 77 days time.

The last thing we want is the petition to remove LGBT content from the curriculum to be debated and our opinion not to be heard.

Please sign if you are a UK citizen or resident & boost if you are not.

May I thank each & every one of the amazing people that that have boosted this message 3,005 times.
💖 ❤️ ❤️ 💖 💖

title: My friend is in university and taking a history class. The professor is using ChatGPT to write essays on the history topics and the students need to mark up its essays and point out where ChatGPT is wrong and correct it.

last_post.content:
Reddit: "My friend is in university and taking a history class. The professor is using ChatGPT to write essays on the history topics and the students need to mark up its essays and point out where ChatGPT is wrong and correct it."

https://old.reddit.com/r/ChatGPT/comments/117gtom/my_friend_is_in_university_and_taking_a_history/

Honestly, this is great! The students learn to check sources, discover that ChatGPT is unreliable, *and* can't use it to generate essay question answers for them, all at the same time!

title: nature.com/articles/d41586-023...

last_post.content:
Many scholars are leaving Twitter for #Mastodon, a public, decentralized alternative, impervious to private take-over:

https://www.science.org/content/article/musk-reshapes-twitter-academics-ponder-taking-flight

Scholarly organizations are already supporting this migration:

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00486-3

and

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7643817

There are analogous solutions for another public good in private hands: journals. There are even levers the scholarly community could pull to incentivize an analogous migration:

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5526634

What are we waiting for?

title: Extracting Training Data from Diffusion Models

last_post.content:
This time Google does the right thing - while shareholders grill them over "competition" with ChatGPT (not really...), they research and publish how useful and privacy preserving large models are.

It turns out, as suspected, they are not very useful for actual professional writers who understand "something" about writing: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05030

...and leak the dataset/private data, 2x worse with diffusion than GANs: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13188

No wonder Google is hesitant to use them. :)

title: Against Predictive Optimization

last_post.content: We looked at > 100 papers on flaws of specific predictive optimization applications. Seven recurring clusters emerged. Given the technical architecture of predictive optimization (vs other forms of automated decision making) we show that this is exactly what we should expect. That made us ask: does *every* predictive optimization application have these flaws? We picked 8 case studies based on prevalence and impact on people. Among these, the answer seems to be yes. https://predictive-optimization.cs.princeton.edu/

It seems as though the Sydney chatbot was experimentally used in India and Indonesia before being unrolled in the US, and manifested some of the same issues with them being noticed. title: StreetPass for Mastodon

last_post.content:
StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

Visit https://streetpass.social/ to try it yourself!

Great work by @brembs et al, which points to the core issue: the private ownership of public commons.

title: How Close is ChatGPT to Human Experts? Comparison Corpus, Evaluation, and Detection

last_post.content:
How Close is #ChatGPT to Human Experts? Comparison Corpus, Evaluation, and Detection

Guo et al.: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07597

"We collected tens of thousands of comparison responses from both human experts and ChatGPT, with questions ranging from open-domain, financial, medical, legal, and psychological areas. We call the collected dataset the Human ChatGPT Comparison Corpus (HC3)."

The authors have used these datasets to evaluate various detection approaches: https://github.com/Hello-SimpleAI/chatgpt-comparison-detection

#ChatGPT #AI

title: https://find.sciences.social

last_post.content:
My winter break project was an app to browse and follow academics from many of the lists on the Academics on Mastodon page.

https://find.sciences.social reads data from the lists, and makes it easy to see profiles and follow academics.

The app doesn't scrape or store any information - it just shows the cdv-files in a new and (I hope) more useful way.

Give it a try.

title: Companies Can’t Ask You to Shut up to Receive Severance, NLRB Rules

last_post.content:
This is HUGE.

"The National Labor Relations Board ruled Tuesday that employers can no longer demand laid-off employees avoid publicly disparaging the company as part of their severance agreements, nor can they stop affected employees from disclosing the terms of their exit packages. Doing so, the federal agency determined, would be a violation of the laid-off employees’ rights under the National Labor Relations Act."

title: Learning-Rate-Free Learning by D-Adaptation

last_post.content:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07733
'Learning-Rate-Free Learning by D-Adaptation'
- Aaron Defazio, Konstantin Mishchenko

The informational complexity of optimising convex, Lipschitz functions depends on the distance of the initial state to the true minimiser, which is typically unknown in practice. This work presents an adaptive scheme for estimating this distance, and shows that the resulting algorithm is then essentially rate-optimal, up to log factors.

#sparxivdigest

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2212.03551.pdf

last_post.content:
Following a trail from John Naughton’s article about the fediverse restoring human communication, I read his previous article on ChatGPT, and that took me to Murray Shanahan on human language, and LLM models as predictive sequences of words designed to seem likely.

“Sequences of words with a propositional form are not special to the model itself in the way they are to us. The model itself has no notion of truth or falsehood, properly speaking, because it lacks the means to exercise these concepts in anything like the way we do.”

This is helping me to understand my feeling that what is at stake here is compositional language that is special to us. It matters, for this profound reason.

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2212.03551.pdf

@Autumm @grammargirl

title: Big Tech lobbyist language made it verbatim into NY’s hedged repair bill

last_post.content:
Documents surrounding the drafting and debate of New York's right-to-repair bill show that many of the changes signed by Governor Hochul were the same as those proposed by a tech trade organization that represents Apple, Google, and other companies.
https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2023/02/report-reveals-the-influence-big-tech-lobbyists-had-on-new-yorks-repair-bill/?utm_brand=ars

title: More buses in disadvantaged areas better value than major transport projects, Australian research finds

last_post.content:
NEW: In new suburbs, this Australian study showed that local bus services would only need to carry 8-9 passengers an hour for its societal benefits to outweigh the financial cost of running the bus.

Too often we say that running a bus service “costs too much,” when in fact it costs too much to NOT run it.

#cities #PublicTransit

https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/feb/03/more-buses-in-underprivileged-areas-better-bang-for-buck-than-new-transport-projects-australian-research-finds

title: Pretraining Language Models with Human Preferences

last_post.content:
RT @tomekkorbak@twitter.com

You can (and should) do RL from human feedback during pretraining itself! In our new paper, we show how training w/ human preferences early on greatly reduces undesirable LM behaviors, including under adversarial attack, w/o hurting downstream performance. https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08582

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/tomekkorbak/status/1628088313252052993

title: Firms stick to four-day week after trial ends

last_post.content:
Firms stick to four-day week after trial ends
"staff are doing 2% more in four days than they used to do in five. The team is happier. Absenteeism has shrunk by two-thirds and applications to work are flooding in."

Those results reflect the overall findings of the report: that staff were much less inclined to call in sick, and more inclined to stay with their employer, reducing recruitment costs and making it more worthwhile training staff.
#news #GoodNews
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-64669987

title: scikit-learn.org/stable/tutori...

last_post.content:
@vicki I like this one: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/tutorial/machine_learning_map/index.html

But my usual approach is "XGBoost for tabular data Neural nets for everything else". And it's mostly based on data shape. Is it regular data, like maps, grids, images: conv-nets. Time-series: transformers or RNNs, depending on compute and size of the data.

Clustering is for data insight, visualization or getting a data-driven classification problem.

Like that or am I misunderstanding the task?

title: Two women mistakenly issued the same Social Security number, resulting in identity mess

last_post.content:
A very Asian American nightmare: These two young immigrant women—both named Jieun Kim, one living in Los Angeles and one in Evanston, IL—were accidentally issued the same social security number by the SSA. Since then they’ve been denied credit, had bank accounts shut down, are in legal limbo when it comes to residency and officially, per the government, are one person with four biological parents.
https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/two-women-one-social-security-number-mighty-big-mess-rcna70808

title: Supreme Court considers if Google is liable for recommending ISIS videos

last_post.content:
In the Section 230 SCOTUS hearing, Justice Gorsuch touched in passing on a question that could have *big* future implications for tech giants: Could they be held liable for the output of generative AI, like ChatGPT or Bing "Sydney?"

Gorsuch hypothesizes the answer is a clear "yes." I wrote a quick post on this as part of our live blog: https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/02/21/gonzalez-v-google-section-230-supreme-court/#link-RMDPP4IT4JCWDHVL37YAKTJ2NI

title: Tilt Doom

last_post.content: A playable version of #DOOM on an #LEGO brick using a @Raspberry_Pi #RP2040 by @ancientjames. Uses an accelerometer and tilt for movement, and a capacitance touch sensor to shoot. Subframe sampling to make the tiny monochrome LCD give 8 gray levels (not 3 like I originally thought!). This is miraculous stuff. 😮 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o76U0JPrMFk

title: The 4 Day Week UK Pilot Programme Results — 4 Day Week Global

last_post.content:
Results of the world’s first coordinated pilot program for a 4 day week in 61 companies with 2,900 workers in the UK are astounding.

Companies continuing with 4 day week: 92%
Average revenue vs last year: +35%
Improved physical health: 37%
Improved mental health: 43%
Absenteeism: decreased
Employee attrition: -57%
Reduced burnout: 71%
Reduced stress: 39%
Better sleep: 40%
Hiring: easier

#4DayWorkWeek #labor ✊🌹

https://www.4dayweek.com/uk-pilot-results

last_post.content:
If Big Journalism doesn't start treating the Murdoch family's poison-spewing Fox "News" like the rogue propaganda-for-power-and-money outfit that it is, the craft will demonstrate its utter contempt for journalistic ethics.

The Fox-McCarthy partnership is one of the most egregious examples yet -- and simply covering it as just another story is not nearly enough.

The times grow more and more dangerous, and Big Journalism is not up to the job -- yet. https://www.cnn.com/2023/02/20/politics/kevin-mccarthy-tucker-carlson-january-6-footage/index.html

title: Supreme Court considers if Google is liable for recommending ISIS videos

last_post.content:
DEVELOPING: The Supreme Court is starting oral arguments on Gonzalez v. Google, a case about Section 230 that could transform the internet, depending on its outcome.

I'm live-blogging the arguments for the Washington Post along with Robert Barnes, Cristiano Lima, and Gerrit de Vynck. You can follow our coverage here: https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/02/21/gonzalez-v-google-section-230-supreme-court/

title: Supreme Court won't upset Arkansas anti-Israel boycott law

last_post.content:
SCOTUS lets a bad Eighth Circuit ruling stand, in which the en banc court ruled against a paper that was financially penalized, under Arkansas state law, for refusing to sign a pledge not to boycott Israel as a condition for running ads from a state university.

Immediately bad for the Eighth Circuit, and probably bad as well for other, generally red, states whose legislatures might be happy to try their luck with this.
https://apnews.com/article/politics-arkansas-state-government-kansas-arizona-israel-9b34e1a01b24f4b6960ca6ed5e71da38

title: Kevin C. Elliott, Values in Science - PhilPapers

last_post.content: If people want to have an informed discussion on the role of values in science, I can highly recommend reading the recent book by Elliott (2022) https://philpapers.org/rec/ELLVIS. It provides a good overview of essential conceptual distinctions (the difference between epistemic and non-epistemic values) that you won't get from social media.

title: Genetically Modified Trees Planted in U.S. Forest for First Time

last_post.content:

(Predictably, one of the founders came from OpenAI)

title: Message from The Artist - Anil Dash - Medium

last_post.content:
Back in 1996, I archived Prince's own first-person narrative of why he changed his name, which he briefly published on his website and then quickly pulled down. After his passing, I brought it back online for the first time in two decades.The long-lost "Message from The Artist": https://medium.com/@anildash/message-from-the-artist-c611535da21c

"I was beyond frustrated with my lack of control over my career and music."

title: 'Case Logics: A Catalog of Intellectual Furnishings' with Shannon Mattern : Arthur F. Kinney Center for Interdisciplinary Renaissance Studies : UMass Amherst

last_post.content:
Thurs, Feb 24, at 5pm ET I'll be talking *online* abt the "Postures of Pandemic Productivity: Work-From-Home Furniture + Information Labor" with the Five Colleges Seminar in Book History.

I'm still writing this damn thing, but I *think* I'll be discussing pandemic bookshelves + Room Rater, the cathartic aesthetics of covid renovations + organizational projects, the history of work-from-home furnishings, + the various postures + politics of domestic information labor?

https://www.umass.edu/renaissance/event/bookhistmattern2023
